p: Cereals are rich in polysaccharides, protein, and phenolic compounds, and are valuable resources for inhibitors of amylase and glucosidase (Figure 1). AIs have been found in cereals such as wheat, barley, sorghum, rye, and rice (Elbein, 1991; Mishra et al., 2017; Pradeep & Sreerama, 2015; Premakumara et al., 2013). The wheat AI isolated by Maeda et al. ( 1985) is the most studied inhibitors in cereals. It has been reported that taking a wheat amylase inhibitor for 9 weeks after meals can reduce postprandial amylase levels, delay carbohydrate digestion and absorption, and lower blood glucose levels without altering pancreas growth (Bernfeld, 1955). In this part, the recent advances made in discovery of starch hydrolase inhibitors from cereals are summarized.
